titleStmt.title: Numerical solution of doubly singular nonlinear systems using neural networks-based integrated intelligent computing

affiliation.orgName: Capital University of Science and Technology
Hamdard Institute of Engineering and Technology

analytic.title: Numerical solution of doubly singular nonlinear systems using neural networks-based integrated intelligent computing

biblStruct.note: Received: 8 December 2016 / Accepted: 15 June 2017 Ó The Natural Computing Applications Forum 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, a bio-inspired computational intelligence technique is presented for solving nonlinear doubly singular system using artificial neural networks (ANNs), genetic algorithms (GAs), sequential quadratic programming (SQP) and their hybrid GA-SQP. The power of ANN models is utilized to develop a fitness function for a doubly singular nonlinear system based on approximation theory in the mean square sense. Global search for the parameters of networks is performed with the competency of GAs and later on fine-tuning is conducted through efficient local search by SQP algorithm. The design methodology is evaluated on number of variants for two point doubly singular systems. Comparative studies with standard results validate the correctness of proposed schemes. The consistent correctness of the proposed technique is proven through statistics using different performance indices.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The singular boundary value problems (BVPs) of differential equations are considered to be the difficult systems arising extensively in the field of applied mathematics and physics such as astrophysics, gas dynamics, chemical reactions, nuclear physics, atomic structure, atomic calculations and study of nonlinear elliptic systems [1][2][3][4]. Due to utmost importance of these problems, research community has shown great interest in solving singular BVPs numerically and analytically including Bessel functions-based monotone iterative technique [5], improved iterative method [6], homotopy perturbation method [7], uniform mesh finite difference method [8], monotone iterative method with eigenfunction expansion [9], modified Adomian decomposition method [10], Borel-Laplace transforms [11] and power series solution [12]. All these numerical schemes are developed on deterministic procedures having advantages and disadvantages in multiple applications of nonlinear singular systems. Besides the extensive use of stochastics numerical techniques for solving effectively nonlinear systems [13][14][15][16], these solvers look promising alternative to be exploited solving variety of stiff problems based on doubly singular nonlinear systems.
In the present study, a computational intelligence procedure is applied for solving the doubly singular nonlinear systems and its generic form with BVPs based on secondorder model is written as
div.formula: pðxÞy 0 ðxÞ ð Þ 0 ¼ qðxÞf x; yðxÞ ð Þ; 0\x 1;ð1Þ
div.p: subject to boundary conditions of Dirichlet type
div.formula: yð0Þ ¼ a 1 ; yð1Þ ¼ c 1ð2Þ
div.p: or boundary conditions of mixed type
div.formula: y 0 ð0Þ ¼ 0; ay 1 ð Þ þ by 0 ð1Þ ¼ c;ð3Þ
div.p: where each element of set [a, a 1 , c 1 ] is assigned positive values greater than zero, b is a constant with b C 0, while the c is any finite constant. In the case of p 0 = 0, Eq. ( 1) is a singular problem, while it is transformed into doubly singular system if q t is considered to be discontinued along with p 0 = 0. The intention of studying the generalized form of the doubly singular BVP and its solutions is to improve the understanding of the system and to develop stochastic solvers to investigate in numerical solutions of these equations.

The stochastic procedures based on neural networks optimized with hybrid schemes consist of global and local adaptation mechanisms and are used extensively for the solutions of nonlinear differential equation models. Few significant recent examples include the solution of mathematical models arising in electrical conducting solids [17,18], combustion theory problems [19], nonlinear pantograph systems [20], Thomas-Fermi equation of an atom [21], fuzzy-type nonlinear differential systems [22], nonlinear Navier-Stoke systems [23], Volterra integral system [24,25], nanofluidics problems [26], Fredholm integral problems [27], thermodynamics studies [28], nonlinear singular Flierl-Petviashivili systems [29], fractional control problems [30], bilinear programming problems [31], nonlinear Jeffery-Hamel flow studies involving nanomaterials [32], nonlinear Bratu-type systems [33] and problems in electromagnetic theory [34]. These contributions motivate the authors to investigate in soft computingbased algorithms to get the viable solutions for brutal boundary value problems (BVPs) of second-order doubly singular nonlinear system represented in Eqs. (1)- (3).

In this study, unsupervised feed-forward artificial neural network (ANN) model for the system (1-3) is constructed and later on optimized globally by genetic algorithms (GAs) and locally by efficient sequential quadratic programming (SQP) algorithm. The design schemes are evaluated on different cases of linear and nonlinear doubly singular BVPs to validate the correctness of the approaches. The viability of the proposed scheme is examined through a large dataset generated by multiple runs of the optimizers, GA-SQP, to get the designed variables of the networks.

The organization for the rest of the article is as follows: in Sect. 2, designed methodology for doubly singular BVPs problem is presented that consists of feed-forward ANN modeling and learning procedures based on GA-SQP algorithms, numerical experimentation for all three problems for each case are provided in Sect. 3, performance analysis through statistics is given in Sect. 4, while the concluding remarks along with few future research directions are given in the last section.

div.head: Designed methodology
div.p: The description of the designed methodology is presented here that consists of two phases for solving doubly singular BVPs. In first phase, approximation theory in mean square error sense is exploited to develop unsupervised feed-forward ANN models for the given system, while in second phase, the procedure for training of the weights of ANN models is narrated based on GAs and SQP algorithms. The graphical abstract of the proposed methodology is shown in Fig. 1.

div.head: Neural network modeling
div.p: The use of ANNs has been extensively reported in the solution of differential equations containing integer and fractional derivative terms [35][36][37][38][39][40]. Mathematical model for the doubly singular BVPs is given by feed-forward ANN in the form of following continuous mapping for the solution y(x), and its nth-order derivative is given, respectively, as:
div.formula: ŷðxÞ ¼ X k i¼1 a i uðw i x þ b i Þ ð 4Þ d n dx n ŷ ¼ X k i¼1 a i d n dx n uðw i x þ b i Þ:ð5Þ
div.p: Necessary details of networks (4-5) can be seen in [35][36][37][38][39][40].

Log-sigmoid transform function, u(x) = 1/1(1 ? e -x ), is used in the hidden layer of the network. The appropriate combination of the equations given in Eqs. (4)(5) is used to develop the neural network model of the doubly singular BVPs of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) as given in (1)(2)(3). The neural network architecture in terms of input, output and hidden layers is shown in Fig. 2. An objective or fitness function is developed in an unsupervised manner, and it is defined by sum of two mean square errors as
div.formula: Neural Comput & Applic 123 E ¼ E 1 þ E 2 ;
div.p: ð6Þ where E 1 is the error function associated with ODE (1) and it is given as
div.formula: E 1 ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 p m y 0 m À Á 0 Àq m f x m ; y m ð Þ 2 ; x 2 0; 1 ð Þ; N ¼ 1 h ; ŷm ¼ ŷ x m ð Þ; p m ¼ pðx m Þ; q m ¼ qðx m Þ and x m ¼ mh:ð7Þ
div.p: Similarly, E 2 is the error function associated with boundary conditions (2) and it is given for Dirichlet type condition as:
div.formula: E 2 ¼ 1 2 ŷ0 À a 1 ð Þ 2 þ ŷN À c 1 ð Þ 2 :ð8Þ
div.p: While in case of mixed conditions (3), the error function E 2 is given as:
div.formula: E 2 ¼ 1 2 ŷ0 0 À Á 2 þ aŷ N þ bŷ 0 N À c À Á 2 :ð9Þ
div.p: The Problem Doubly Singular BVPs

div.head: Learning methodology
div.p: Genetics algorithm belongs to the class of evolutionary computational intelligence techniques inspired by the process of natural evolution and has been used extensively in many optimization problems in diverse field of engineering and applied sciences [41][42][43][44][45]. The main aim of the GAs is to search a good candidate solution of specific optimization problem by exploring thoroughly the search space using its famous operators of selection, crossover and mutation. Recent application of evolutionary computing includes optimization of model for induction motors [46], nanocatalysts optimization systems [47], modeling of nonlinear Jeffery-Hamel flow problem [48] and study of physical and chemical properties of nanooxides [49].

When the number of generations in GAs for any optimization problems increases, the speed of convergence degrades considerably; therefore, it is always desirable to hybrid the GAs with an efficient local search algorithm for speedy fine-tuning. The SQP algorithm is an efficient and reliable deterministic procedure used immensely for solving nonlinear constraints optimization equations and can be a good local search method. The motivation to use SQP is due to its wide use in optimization problems such as economic production quantity problems [50], economic load dispatch problems [51] and plasma physics problems [52].

Keeping in view these facts, GAs hybrid with SQP method is used for adaptation of fitness function given in Eqs. ( 6)- (9). In numerical simulation studies, software packages of Matlab and Mathematica environment are used to get the desire solution of the optimization problem. Built-in software routines for GAs and SQP are used for optimization of neural networks. Workflow diagram of the proposed methodology is given in Fig. 1, while the necessary details of procedural steps are given in the following pseudocode.
div.formula: Optimization Local Search: AcƟve-set Method q() p() x + α u (wx+ ).α ŷ (x) x p(x)ŷ''(x)+p (x) ŷ'(x) = q(x)f(x, y) Input Hidden Layer (0, X) Output f (x) = 1/(1+e -x ) u' () wx+ u() u'' () α α u (wx+ ).α u'' (wx+ ).α x + ŷ(x) ŷ''(x) = 0 x -f(x,

div.head: Improvements:
div.p: Sequential quadratic programming technique is used for further refinement of results by taking final adaptive weights of GAs as initial weights (start point) of SQP algorithm. SQP is applied as per setting of parameters (TolFun 10 -20 , TolX 10 -20 , TolCon 0, Iterations = 750 and default).

div.head: Storage:
div.p: Store the refined final weights of the algorithm. Repeat the process for reliable infereneces.

div.head: Numerical experimentations
div.p: In this section, results of numerical experimentation for the proposed scheme are presented to three different doubly singular BVPs for number of variants.

div.head: Problem 1
div.p: Linear doubly singular with polynomial type forcing function: In this case, doubly singular BVP based on second-order linear, non-homogeneous ordinary differential equation (ODE) having polynomial type forcing function is considered. The general form of such equation derived from expression (1) subject to boundary conditions is given as:
div.formula: y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 x y 0 x ð Þ þ ay ¼ f x ð Þ y(0) = 1 , y(1) = 3 (ð10Þ
div.p: The exact solution of Eq. ( 10) is known and given as:
div.formula: yðxÞ ¼ 1 þ x þ x 3 :ð11Þ
div.p: Three cases of problem (10) are taken using different values of a and forcing function f(x) to test the given scheme.
Case 1 Doubly singular BVP (10)
div.formula: for a ¼ À9 and f x ð Þ ¼ À9 À 9x 3 þ 1
div.p: x is given as:
div.formula: y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 x y 0 x ð Þ À 9y ¼ À9 À 9x 3 þ 1 x :ð12Þ
div.p: The fitness function for ( 12) is formulated similar to Eq. ( 6) as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À 9x m ŷm þ 9x m þ 9x 4 m À 1 À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À 3Þ 2 :ð13Þ
div.p: Case 2 Doubly singular BVP (10)
div.formula: for a ¼ À1 and f x ð Þ ¼ À1 À x 3 þ 8x þ 1
div.p: x is taken in this case as:
div.formula: y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 x y 0 x ð Þ À y ¼ À1 À x 3 þ 8x þ 1 x :ð14Þ
div.p: The fitness function for ( 14) is formulated as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À x m ŷm þ x m þ x 4 m À 8x 2 À 1 À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À 3Þ 2 :ð15Þ
div.p: Case 3 Doubly singular BVP (10) for a ¼ 1 and
div.formula: f x ð Þ ¼ 1 þ x 3 þ 10x þ 1
div.p: x is considered in this case as:
div.formula: y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 x y 0 x ð Þ þ y ¼ 1 þ x 3 þ 10x þ 1 x :ð16Þ
div.p: The fitness function for the case is given as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m þ x m ŷm À x m À x 4 m À 10x 2 À 1 À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À 3Þ 2 :ð17Þ
div.p: The integrating computing approach based on GA-SQP method is used as an optimization solver to get the unknown variable of ANNs for the fitness functions given in Eqs. ( 13), ( 15) and ( 17), for cases 1, 2 and 3, respectively, of doubly singular BVP (10). One of the weights obtained by the application of GA-SQP algorithm according to the procedure explained in last section for case 1 is shown in Fig. 2 together with graphical representation of iterative update of SQP based on total function evaluations, current function values and step sizes. The weights shown in these plots are used in ANN models to get the approximate solutions of doubly singular BVP (10) for each case as:

The weights are given in appendix with values of parameters such that no round off error problem arises. With the help of Eqs. ( 18), ( 19) and ( 20), the approximate solutions y ˆ(x) are obtained by the proposed design approach in case of input x as 0, with step size of 0.05. A comparison of proposed solutions y ˆ(x) with the exact solutions y(x) is made for the same inputs, and results are given in Table 1. The performance of the proposed scheme is analyzed by defining absolute error (AE) as:
div.formula: AE ¼ yðxÞ À ŷðxÞ j j :
div.p: Smaller the values of AE obtained, the better is the performance of the algorithm. The values of AE are calculated for each case of problem (10), and results are given in Table 1. It is seen that the very small values of MAE are obtained which lie in the range *10 -07 to 10 -09 , *10 -07 to 10 -08 and *10 -06 to 10 -08 for case 1, 2 and 3, respectively, of doubly singular BVP of problem 1. The smaller values of AEs established the correctness of the design method (Fig. 3).

div.head: Problem II
div.p: Linear doubly singular BVP with variable coefficients In this case, linear doubly singular problem BVP of secondorder homogeneous ODE is taken for the analysis. The general form of the equation derived from (1) with boundary conditions is given as [2]:
div.formula: x a y 0 ð Þ 0 ¼ bx aþbÀ2 bx b þ a þ b À 1 À Á y 0\x 1 and a; b [ 0 yð0Þ ¼ 1; yð1Þ¼e &ð21Þ
div.p: The exact solution for Eq. ( 21) is given as: [2]
div.formula: y ¼ e x bð22Þ
div.p: Three different cases of problem ( 21) are formulated using different values of a and b in order to evaluate the performance of the proposed design methodology.
Case 1 For a = 0.5 and b = 1 in problem (21), we have ffiffi ffi
div.formula: x p y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 2 ffiffi ffi x p y 0 x ð Þ ¼ 1 ffiffi ffi x p 2x þ 1 2 y:ð23Þ
div.p: The merit function for (21) for case 1 is formulated as: Fig. 3 Optimization process of proposed scheme GA-SQP for case 1 of doubly singular BVP in problem 1
div.formula: Neural Comput & Applic
E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 2x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À 2x m ŷm À ŷm À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À eÞ 2 :ð24Þ
div.p: Case 2 For a ¼ 0:75 and b = 1 in problem (21), the doubly singular problem is given as:
div.formula: x 3=4 y 00 ðxÞ þ 3 4x 1=4 y 0 x ð Þ ¼ 1 x 1=4 x þ 3 4 y:ð25Þ
div.p: The fitness function for this case is constructed as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 4x m ŷ00 m þ 3ŷ 0 m À 4x m ŷm À 3ŷ m À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À eÞ 2 :ð26Þ
div.p: Case 3 For a ¼ 0:25 and b = 1 in problem ( 21), we get:
div.formula: x 1=4 y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 4x 3=4 y 0 x ð Þ ¼ 1 x 3=4 x þ 1 4 y:ð27Þ
div.p: The fitness function in this case is written as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 4x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À 4x m ŷm À ŷm À Á 2 þ 1 2 ðŷ 0 À 1Þ 2 þ ðŷ N À eÞ 2 :ð28Þ
div.p: Optimization of fitness function (24), ( 26) and ( 28) is carried out by GA-SQP algorithm, and one set of weights obtained for case 1 is shown in Fig. 4. The derived solutions for all the three cases of doubly singular BVP-2 are given mathematically as:

The proposed results are calculated using Eqs. ( 29), (30) and (31), and results are listed in Table 2 along with the exact solution. The values of AE for proposed methodology GA-SQP lie in the range *10 -07 to *10 -08 , *10 -06
to *10 -09 and *10 -07 to *10 -09 for cases 1, 2 and 3 of doubly singular BVP-2, respectively, which confirm the high accuracy and correctness of the given scheme.

div.head: Problem 3
div.p: Nonlinear doubly singular BVP with variable coefficients:

In this case, doubly singular BVP-3 is based on secondorder ODE, which is nonlinear, homogeneous and having variable coefficients. The general form of this equation with boundary conditions is given as:
div.formula: x a y 0 ð Þ 0 ¼ bx aþbÀ2 e y e y x b À a À b þ 1 À Á 0\x 1; a; b [ 0 yð0Þ ¼ ln b 4 ; yð1Þ ¼ ln b 5 8 < :ð32Þ
div.p: The exact solution for (32) is known as: [30]
div.formula: yðxÞ ¼ ln b 4 þ x b :ð33Þ
div.p: Three cases of problem (32) are taken using different values of a and b to test the performance, applicability, reliability of proposed design methodology.
Case 1 The parameters a ¼ 0:25 and b = 1 are used in problem (32), and then, we get:
div.formula: x 1=4 y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 4x 3=4 y 0 x ð Þ ¼ e y x 3=4 xe y À 1 4 yð0Þ ¼ ln1 4
div.p: ; yð1Þ ¼ ln 1 5
The fitness function as given in Eq. ( 6) for this case is formulated as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 4x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À 4x m e 2y m þ e y m À Á 2 þ 1 2 ŷ0 À ln 1 4 2 þ ŷN À ln 1 5 2 ! :ð35Þ
div.p: Case 2 For a ¼ 0:5 and b = 1, Eq. ( 32) is formulated as:
div.formula: x 1=2 y 00 ðxÞ þ 1 2x 1=2 y 0 x ð Þ ¼ e y x 1=2 xe y À 1 2 yð0Þ ¼ ln1 4
div.p: ; yð1Þ ¼ ln 1 5
The fitness function is constructed as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 2x m ŷ00 m þ ŷ0 m À 2x m e 2y m þ e y m À Á 2 þ 1 2 ŷ0 À ln 1 4 2 þ ŷN À ln 1 5 2 ! :ð37Þ
div.p: Case 3 For a ¼ 0:75 and b = 1 in problem (32), we get:
x 3=4 y 00 ðxÞ þ
div.formula: 3 4x 1=4 y 0 x ð Þ ¼ e y x 1=4 xe y À 3 4 yð0Þ ¼ ln 1 4 ; yð1Þ ¼ ln 1 5 8 > > < > > :ð38Þ
div.p: The fitness function for this case is given as:
div.formula: E ¼ 1 N X N m¼1 4x m ŷ00 m þ 3ŷ 0 m À 4x m e 2y m þ 3e y m À Á 2 þ 1 2 ŷ0 À ln 1 4 2 þ ŷN À ln 1 5 2 ! :ð39Þ
div.p: Optimization of fitness function ( 35), ( 37) and ( 39) is performed with GA-SQP to get the desired weight as shown in Fig. 5. The optimal weights are used to get the solutions for cases 1, 2 and 3 of doubly singular BVP-3, respectively, as:

The proposed solutions are determined using Eqs. ( 40), ( 41) and ( 42), and results are listed in Table 3 along with the exact solution. It is clear from the table that the values of AE for proposed methodology lie in the range *10 -08 to *10 -10 , *10 -07 to *10 -08 and *10 -08 to *10 -09 for cases 1, 2 and 3 of doubly singular BVP-3, respectively, which confirm the high accuracy and correctness of the given scheme.

div.head: Analyses through statistics
div.p: Results of statistical analyses based on a large data generated through sufficient number of independent runs can be given in-depth performance of the proposed scheme rather that analysis carried out on a single successful runs of the algorithms. In this regard, 100 independent runs of GA-SQP are performed to optimize ANNs to get the solution for each case of all three problems. The results based on values of mean absolute error (MAE) against number of runs in unsorted form are given in Figs. 6a, 7a and 8a, while sorted ascending value of fitness are given in Figs. 6b, 7b and 8b. In order to differentiate , 7d and8d give the results based on values of fitness for every independent runs of the scheme in unsorted and sorted forms, respectively. It is clear from the figures that lower values of parameters, i.e., fitness and MAE, are obtained for every independent run of designed methodology for all cases of three problems. The performance operators based on three statistical measures, i.e., mean, standard deviation (STD) and minimum (MIN) are also used to validate the accuracy and convergence of the proposed methodology for solving all three doubly singular BVPs. The results in terms of MIN mean and STD values based on MAE calculated for 100 independent runs are listed in Tables 4, 5 and 6 for inputs 0 B x B 1, with step size 0.05 for all three cases of doubly singular BVP-1, 2 and 3. It is found that consistently the smaller values of each of the statistical performance operators are obtained by GA-SQP method which verifies the correctness of the given approach for such stiff nonlinear systems as well.

The performance of the proposed methodology is further analyzed based on value of global operators for all three cases of doubly singular BVP-1, 2 and 3. The two global performance parameters for the accuracy are constructed, i.e., global mean absolute error (G MAE ) and the mean value of fitness (M Fit ) achieved, and are given as:
div.formula: G MAE ¼ 1 R X R r¼1 1 P X P i¼1 jy i À ŷi;r j ! ! ;ð43Þ
M Fit ¼ 1 R X R r¼1 E r ! ;ð44Þ
div.p: where P and R are stand for the total number of inputs grid points and the number of time the algorithm runs, respectively, y i and ŷi;r are the reference exact and proposed approximate solutions of the rth independent run for the ith gird point, and E r is the fitness value achieved for the rth run of the algorithm. In the simulations, we have taken x [ [0, 1] with a step size of 0.05, i.e., number of grid point P = 20 and total number of runs R = 100. In Tables 7,8 and 9, the values of G MAE and M Fit along with their STD for all three cases of doubly singular BVP-1, 2 and 3 are given, respectively. The values of G MAE for proposed methodology GA-SQP are obtained of the order of*10 -05 to *10 -06 for case 1 and *10 -05 for both cases 2 and 3.

Similarly, the values of M Fit for proposed methodology are obtained in *10 -08 for all three cases of the doubly singular BVPs. Smaller values of global performance operators mean that the better is the consistent accuracy of the algorithm in each case of doubly singular BVPs. The computational complexity of the proposed scheme is examined based on the computing time taken for optimization of design parameter of neural networks and average number of generation taken by the algorithm. The analysis is conducted based on 100 independent runs, and results are given in terms of mean execution time (MET) along with its STD, and mean generation (MG) in Tables 7,8, and 9 for problems 1, 2 and 3, respectively. It is found that there is no significant difference in the values of MET and MG for all three cases of problem 1. Similar results are obtained for problems 2 and 3. There is no noticeable difference in the values of M ET , and M Gen lies in the closed vicinity of 50 s and 900 generations, respectively. The smaller values of STD of these operators are obtained for all the three cases of each problem which validate the smooth operation of the scheme in each run of algorithm.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: An artificial intelligence technique based upon feed-forward artificial neural networks, genetic algorithm, sequential quadratic programming is exploited to solve effectively variants of three doubly singular BVPs. Correctness of the design scheme is established based on comparison of the results in terms of AE from reference exact solutions with consistent small values of AE for each case of all three problems. Comparison of proposed results is also made on statistical measures, i.e., mean and STD and global performance operators, G MAE , and G Fit , show that given scheme consistently provides the values of error- In future, the proposed methodology can be extended to solve nonlinear higher-order BVPs with multiple singularity based on ordinary and partial differential equation and their systems. One may look to construct more accurate and reliable neural networks models with transfer functions including radial basis, Mexican hat, Wavelets hat, Morlet, etc., to determine the solution of given stiff nonlinear doubly singular BVPs such as problems arising in electromagnetic theory, circuit analysis and nanotechnology.

div.head: Compliance with ethical standards
div.p: Conflict of interest All the authors of the manuscript declared that there is no conflict of interest.

div.head: Appendix
div.p: Derived solutions of the proposed methodology are listed here by using 14 decimal places of accuracy in the values of the weights of ANN models. The equation listed with same number as in the manuscript for easy reference.
